summary.para: Specifies the scope of the resource lock.
The lock belongs exclusively to the requesting principle. No other principle may modify the locked resource URI.
The locked resource may not be modified by non-trusted principles. Users who have access rights, however, may request a shared lock which they can then use to modify or operate on the resource.
Use Depth to instruct the server on how deep to operate within the collection.
Use the protocol default depth for the operation.
Operate on the target resource URI and all of its internal member URIs recursively.
Operate on the collection resource URI and all of its immediate member resources.
Operate only on the collection resource URI, and not on any of its internal member resources.
This member supports the Clever Internet Suite infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
The connection receives SMTP commands.
The connection receives CRAM-MD5 authorization data.
The connection receives raw message data.
The connection receives NTML authorization data.
The connection receives user password.
The connection receives user name.
Specifies the server action when receiving the email recipient list from client.
Recipient was accepted successfully.
The email address is invalid.
Account disabled.
Email should be forwarded.
User not local, try another address.
Relay denied.
Too many recipients.
Specifies the server action when receiving the email sender address from client.
The email address was accepted successfully.
The email address was rejected.
Specifies the server action when receiving the email message from client.
Requested mail action aborted: exceeded storage allocation.
Message received successfully.
Requested action aborted: error in processing.
Requested action not taken: insufficient system storage.
Transaction failed.
Represents the SMTP connection states.
The client is connected and the server is ready to receive commands.
The server receives email message.
The server received HELO / EHLO command and ready to authorize.
The connection received MAIL FROM command.
The connection receives email recipients.
Specifies whether the component should use the TLS / SSL security protocol.
The component will first connect in plaintext, and then explicitly start SSL negotiation through a protocol command such as STARTTLS. The non-secured communication is allowed.
The component will first connect in plaintext, and then explicitly start SSL negotiation through a protocol command such as STARTTLS. The non-secured communication is not allowed.
The SSL negotiation will start immediately after the connection is established.
No SSL negotiation, no SSL security. All communication will be in plaintext mode.
Specifies SASL authentication method when accepting connections from users.
No SASL authentication.
CRAM-MD5 authentication (a simple challenge-response scheme based on HMAC-MD5).
USER/PASS or LOGIN authentication (a simple cleartext password mechanism).
NTLM authentication (an NT LAN Manager authentication mechanism).
This member supports the Clever Internet Suite infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
The connection receives POP3 commands.
The connection receives CRAM-MD5 authorization data.
The connection receives NTML authorization data.
This member supports the Clever Internet Suite infrastructure and is not intended to be used directly from your code.
The POP3 connection ready to authorize.
The POP3 connection is in transaction state.
The POP3 connection is in update state.
Specifies POP3 authentication mode.
Makes all possible authentication methods available during establishing the client session.
Makes both USER/PASS and APOP authentication methods available during establishing the client session.
Makes one of Simple Authentication and Security Layer (SASL) methods available during establishing the client session. Use the SaslFlags property for choosing SASL authentication methods.
Specifies file access permissions when connecting via FTP protocol.
Execute permission.
No permissions.
Read permission.
Write permission.
Represents the comression strategies for the GZip deflate / inflate functionality.
The default strategy.
This strategy will only allow longer string repetitions. It is useful for random data with a small character set.
The fixed strategy.
This strategy will not look for string repetitions at all. It only encodes with Huffman trees (which means, that more common characters get a smaller encoding.
This method is not implemented.
Represents the comression levels for the GZip deflate / inflate functionality.
The best and slowest compression level. This tries to find very long and distant string repetitions.
The worst but fastest compression level.
The default compression level.
This level won't compress at all but output uncompressed blocks.
Represents the TLS / SSL client connection mode.

If the Port property is set to the standard plaintext port of the protocol, the component will behave the same as if UseTls property is set to Explicit. In all other cases, SSL negotiation will be Implicit.
The component will first connect in plaintext, and then explicitly start SSL negotiation through a protocol command such as STARTTLS.
The SSL negotiation will start immediately after the connection is established.
No SSL negotiation, no SSL security. All communication will be in plaintext mode.
